content: The Act may be cited as the "Diabetic Retinopathy Prevention Act of 2003". The Congress finds that type 2 diabetes affects millions of Americans, leading to diabetic retinopathy which can cause blindness. The risk of diabetic retinopathy increases with the duration of diabetes, and early detection is crucial. The risk of diabetic retinopathy increases with the duration of diabetes. Early detection and treatment can reduce vision loss by 90 percent. Remote assessment has the potential to reach diabetic patients in rural or underserved areas lacking access to in-office eye examinations. Medicare coverage is expanded to include remote assessment of diabetic retinopathy, aiming to reach patients in rural or underserved areas without access to in-office eye exams. The term 'remote assessment of diabetic retinopathy' refers to a diagnostic examination of the retina for early detection of diabetic retinopathy, provided annually to individuals diagnosed with diabetes. The examination must meet technical standards set by the Secretary and be conducted via a telecommunications system by qualified healthcare professionals. The amendments allow for remote assessments of diabetic retinopathy to be provided to eligible patients by qualified healthcare professionals using store-and-forward technologies for asynchronous transmission of health care information. The amendments allow for remote assessments of diabetic retinopathy to be furnished through store-and-forward technologies for asynchronous transmission of health care information. The Secretary will provide payment for retinopathy assessments under a new HCPCS code. The Secretary will conduct a study on diabetic retinopathy services, analyzing per-patient and administrative costs. A report with recommendations on reimbursements and the need for repeated studies will be submitted to Congress within 2 years. Amends Title III of the Public Health Service Act to establish a Mobile Diabetic Retinopathy Screening Pilot Program. The Secretary will establish a grant program called the "Mobile Diabetic Retinopathy Screening Pilot Program" to fund mobile diabetic retinopathy screening programs. Grants will be limited to $1,000,000 per year, and eligible entities must agree to use the funds for this specific purpose. Applications must be submitted within 90 days of funding availability.
